sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: From its website, dtach is a tiny program that emulates the detach feature of screen, allowing you to run a program in an environment that is protected from the controlling terminal and attach to it later.

sections.title: Create a new session
sections.content:
To create a new session running command and attach to it:

```
$ dtach -c socket command
```

For example, to create a new session running bash with the socket located at /tmp/bashsession:

```
$ dtach -c /tmp/bashsession bash
```

To create a new session running command without attaching to it:

```
$ dtach -n socket command
```

sections.title: Attach to a session
sections.content:
To attach to an existing session:

```
$ dtach -a socket
```

To attach to an existing session, and if not already existing, create it:

```
$ dtach -A socket
```

sections.title: Detach from a session
sections.content: In an attached session, type Ctrl+\. This key combination can be modified with the -e flag.

sections.title: Share a session
sections.content: To share a session with another user, simply #Create a new session and change the permissions on the socket file such that the other user can read and write to it. Then the other user should be able to attach to the session.
